Hi Rich - 

Yes, nice tsuba. It definitely is kiri, not wysteria motif. If Akasaka I would expect to see some linear "bones" in the edge of the tsuba from folding. I can see Akasaka or as you said, Tosa Myochi...or dare I say Higo, Nishigaki work perhaps? Whatever, it is nice. 

Ron
STL 
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Tom Helm 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, May 12, 2004 7:44 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Akasaka Tsuba redux


  Rich-
        I would be more inclined to say Kiri (Paluwonia), rather than Fuji 
  (Wisteria), looking especially at the top. I think the crescents are 
  just openings and not representative of any object...
  -t

  Nice piece, nice presentation too.
